videoData.title: How women will lead us to freedom, justice and peace
videoData.socialTitle: How women will lead us to freedom, justice and peace

takeAction.blurb: **Learn more** about the Ellen Johnson Sirleaf Center for Women and Development.

nodes.whoTheyAre: The former President of Liberia, Nobel laureate H.E. Ellen Johnson Sirleaf promotes freedom, peace, justice, women’s empowerment and democratic rule.
nodes.whyListen:
As Africa's first democratically elected female president, H.E. Ellen Johnson Sirleaf led Liberia's recovery following a decade-long civil war, and helped stem the nation's Ebola crisis of 2014-2015. Recognized as a global leader for women's rights, President Sirleaf was awarded the Nobel Prize for Peace in 2011.

President Sirleaf received the United States's Presidential Medal of Freedom for her unwavering commitment to expanding freedom and improving the lives of Africans. Her many honors include the Grand Croix of the Légion d’Honneur (France's highest public distinction) and being named one of Forbes's "100 Most Powerful Women in the World."

videoData.description: "I was the first woman president of an African nation, and I do believe more countries ought to try that," says H.E. Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, Nobel laureate and former president of Liberia. Telling the story of how Liberian women helped rebuild their country after years of civil war, Sirleaf discusses why gender equality is essential to peace and prosperity -- and shares her plan to uplift a generation of women prepared to take leadership positions and catalyze social change.
videoData.socialDescription: "I was the first woman president of an African nation, and I do believe more countries ought to try that," says H.E. Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, Nobel laureate and former president of Liberia. Telling the story of how Liberian women helped rebuild their country after years of civil war, Sirleaf discusses why gender equality is essential to peace and prosperity -- and shares her plan to uplift a generation of women prepared to take leadership positions and catalyze social change.

cues.text: I was the first woman president

And I do believe more countries
ought to try that.
Once the glass ceiling has been broken,
it can never be put back together --
however one would try to do that.
When I assumed the presidency of Liberia

we faced the tremendous challenges
of a post-conflict nation:
the challenges of those left behind.
The primary victims of all civil wars:

It had been a very long climb

I recruited a very able economist

to address the fears of our women,

Another to be the minister of gender,

to be able to ensure the protection
and the participation of women.
